alert.note: Alert for Montgomery (Pennsylvania) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Philadelphia - Mount Holly (New Jersey, Delaware, Southeastern Pennsylvania)
info.headline: Flood Warning issued July 09 at 9:50PM EDT until July 10 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Philadelphia - Mount Holly
info.description: ...The National Weather Service in Mount Holly NJ has issued a Flood Warning for the following rivers in Pennsylvania... Schuylkill River At Pottstown affecting Montgomery County. Schuylkill River At Norristown affecting Montgomery, Chester, and Philadelphia Counties. Schuylkill River At Philadelphia affecting Montgomery and Philadelphia Counties. ...FLOOD WARNING IN EFFECT UNTIL TOMORROW EVENING... * WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Schuylkill River At Pottstown. * WHEN...Until tomorrow evening. * IMPACTS...At 11.0 feet, Sewers in the Pottstown area, due to high and backwater effects, begin to flood. At 12.5 feet, Portions of PA Route 724 along the Berks/Chester county line begin to flood, specifically Union Township in Berks county and North Coventry Township in Chester county. At 13.0 feet, Portions of PA Route 724 along the Berks/Chester county line are closed due to high water, specifically Union Township in Berks county and North Coventry Township in Chester county. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 9:30 PM EDT Sunday the stage was 11.3 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage late this evening to a crest of 15.0 feet tomorrow morning. It will then fall below flood stage tomorrow afternoon. - Flood stage is 12.5 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 15.1 feet on 03/12/1936. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood && Stream Fld Observed Fcsts (8 pm) Crest Location Stg Stg Day/Time Mon Tue Stg Time Date Schuylkill River Pottstown 12.5 11.3 Sun 9 pm 11.1 6.0 15.0 8am 7/10 &&
info.instruction: Turn around...don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the dangers of flooding. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov/phi. The next statement will be issued Monday morning by 1000 AM EDT.
